questions.text: Consider a sphere of radius R which carries a uniform charge density ρ. If a sphere of radius  R 2  is carved out of it, as shown, the ratio  | E → A | | E → B |  of magnitude of electric field  E → A  and  E → B , respectively, at points A and B due to the remaining portion is:
questions.solution:
E A = σ ( R / 2 ) 3 ε 0 = σ R 6 ε 0
E B = σ R 3 ε 0 – 1 4 π ε 0 ( σ ) 3 R 2 2 4 π 3 R 2 3
= σ R 3 ε 0 – σ R 54 ε 0
⇒       E B = 17 54 σ R ε 0
E A E B = 1 × 54 6 × 17 = 9 17
questions.new_possible_concepts:
· Gauss law is useful for calculation of electric field due to symmetric charge distribution.
· Principle of superposition can be used to calculate electric field due to a combination of various charge distributions.

questions.text: An electric field    E     →      =    4    x        i     ^      −    (     y     2      +    1      )         j     ^          N/C       passes through the box shown in figure. The flux of the electric field through surfaces ABCD and BCGF are marked as   ϕ    I      and   ϕ   I   I     respectively. The difference between  (   ϕ   I    −   ϕ   I I    )       is (in Nm2/C) ______.
questions.solution:
ϕ I = ∫ E → . d A → = 0
ϕ   I I   = [   4 x   i   ^   − (   y   2   + 1   )   j   ^   ] .4   i   ^  
            = 16 x  
ϕ   I I   =   48 N   m   2   C  
ϕ   I   −   ϕ   I I   = − 48
questions.new_possible_concepts:
• Physically electric flux represents the number of field lines passing through a given area. 
  •   ϕ =   ∫       E   →   −   d s   →

questions.text: Three charged particles A, B and C with charges –4q, 2q and –2q are present on the circumference of a circle of radius d. The charged particles A, C and centre O of the circle formed an equilateral triangle as shown in figure. Electric field at O along x-direction is
questions.solution:
Electric field due to charge +2q at centre O –  

E   →   1   =   1   4   π   ε   0   2   q   d   2   +   3   i   ^   −   j   ^   2  
Due to –2q  

E   →   2   =   1   4   π   ε   0   ×   2   q   d   2   3   i   ^   −   j   ^   2  
Due to –4q  

E   →   2   =   1   4   π   ε   0   ×   2   q   d   2   [   3   i   ^   −   j   ^   2   ]  
Net electric field at point O 

E → 0 = E → 1 + E → 2 + E → 3 = 3 q π ε 0 d 2 i ^

questions.text: In finding the electric field using Gauss law the formula  E → = q e n c ε 0 A is applicable. In the formula ε0 is permittivity of free space, A is the area of Gaussian surface and qenc is charge enclosed by the Gaussian surface. This equation can be used in which of the following situation?

choices.text: Only when the Gaussian surface is an equipotential surface and  E   →    is constant on the surface.
Only when  E   →    = constant on the surface.
Only when the Gaussian surface is an equipotential surface.
For any choice of Gaussian surface.

questions.solution:
By Gauss law 

∮ E → ⋅ d A → = Q i n ε 0
If  | E → | = Q i n | A → | ε 0
or  | E → | | A → | = Q i n ε 0
then  E   →   |   |   A   →  
∴ Surface is equipotential too.

questions.text: A particle of mass m and charge q is released from rest in a uniform electric field. If there is no other force on the particle, the dependence of its speed v on the distance x travelled by it is correctly given by (graphs are schematic and not drawn to scale)
questions.solution: v 2    = 2 q E    m      ·   x
questions.underlying_concept: Motion of charge in electric field
questions.new_possible_concepts:
· Force exerted by electric field on a charge particle is given by

F → = q E →

· If a particle is released from rest in uniform force field, then it moves along straight line in the direction of force with uniform acceleration.
· Path of a charged particle in uniform Electric field can be straight line OR parabolic depending on angle between its velocity and Electric field.

questions.text: Two infinite planes each with uniform surface charge density +σ are kept in such a way that the angle between them is 30°. The electric field in the region shown between them is given by

choices.text: σ 2 ε 0 ( 1 + 3 ) y ^ + x ^ 2
σ 2 ε 0 ( 1 + 3 ) y ^ − x ^ 2
σ 2 ε 0 1 – 3 2   y ^ − x ^ 2
σ 2 ε 0 1 + 3 2   y ^ + x ^ 2

questions.solution:
E 1   →   = σ 2 ε 0     y ^  
E 2   →   = σ 2 ε 0   ( – cos 60 °   x ^   – sin 60 ° y ^   )  
= σ 2 ε 0   – 1 2   x ^   – 3   2   y ^  
∴       E P   →   = E 1   →   + E 2   →   = σ 2 ε 0   – 1 2   x ^   + 1 – 3   2   y ^
questions.underlying_concept: Electric field due to infinite plane of charge
questions.new_possible_concepts:
· For calculation of electric field due symmetric charge distribution, gauss law is a useful tool. 
· According to gauss law, flux linked with a closed surface is given by  ϕ     = ∮ E → ⋅ d s → = 1 ε 0 Q enc

questions.text: Charges Q1 and Q2 are at points A and B of a right angle triangle OAB (see figure). The resultant electric field at point O is perpendicular to the hypotenuse, then Q1/Q2 is proportional to
questions.solution:
Net field along AB at O must be zero.
E2 cosα = E1 sinα
k Q 2 x 2 2 ⋅ x 2 A B = k Q 1 x 1 2 ⋅ x 1 A B
Q 1 Q 2 = x 1 x 2
questions.underlying_concept: Electric field due to multiple charges
questions.new_possible_concepts: Net field along AB at O must be zero.

questions.solution:
p   →              p   •   ←  
U   =   –   p   →   ⋅   E   →  
E   →   =   2   p   →   4   π   ε   0   ×   a   3  
∴  Δ   U   l   o   s   s   =   2   p   2   4   π   ε   0   a   3   =   2   ×   1   2   m   v   2  
⇒  v   =   p   a   1   2   π   ε   0   m   a

|Change in energy| = Ui – Uf
Decrease in PE is equal to the Increase in KE
